Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial of Bilateral Deep Brain Stimulation of the Fornix in Mild, Probable Alzheimer’s Disease

Trial_Design.evidence: The ADvance Trial is a multicenter, 12-month, double-blind, randomised, controlled feasibility study.

Participants.evidence: Participants were patients with mild, probable AD, recruited between June 6, 2012, and April 28, 2014.

Intervention.evidence: A total of 42 patients were randomised to receive bilateral fornix DBS.

Objective.evidence: This study aims to assess the safety, efficacy, and tolerability of bilateral deep brain stimulation (DBS) of the fornix in patients with mild, probable Alzheimer’s disease (AD).

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the 90-day perioperative safety of the procedure.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was conducted at the patient level, with allocation concealment ensured.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was maintained for outcome assessors, patients, and clinicians.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 42 patients were randomised to receive bilateral fornix DBS.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Twenty-six patients (61.9%) experienced 64 AEs related to the study procedure, with 7 serious AEs in 5 patients (11.9%).

Harms.evidence: Twenty-six patients (61.9%) experienced 64 AEs related to the study procedure, with 7 serious AEs in 5 patients (11.9%).
